remarks: The intersecting chords theorem. If points A, B, C, and D lie on a circle (with center Q, say), and the point P is on the interior of the segments AB and CD, then the two products of lengths PA ` x. ` PB and PC ` x. ` PD are equal. The Euclidean plane is identified with the complex plane, and the fact that P is on AB and on CD is expressed by the hypothesis that the angles APB and CPD are equal to ` _pi ` . The result is proven by using ~ chordthmlem5 twice to show that PA ` x. ` PB and PC ` x. ` PD both equal BQ<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML> ` - ` PQ<HTML><sup>2</sup></HTML>. This is similar to the proof of the theorem given in Euclid's _Elements_, where it is Proposition III.35. This is Metamath 100 proof #55.  (Contributed by David Moews, 28-Feb-2017.)
